subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit 3 - compatibility - getName() method
msgSnippet: I don t use logging in my tests but since others obviously do here is a tip: With log4j you could use MDC.put( test , getName()); MDC stands for
messageBody:
<off-topic>
I don't use logging in my tests but since others obviously do here is a tip:
With log4j you could use MDC.put("test", getName());

MDC stands for "Mapped Diagnostic Context", what it really does is
assign a map of parameters to the current thread that can be accessed
in your pattern layout like this: %X{test}

So that you can grep for all logitems related to your test by test-name.

I have used this to assign request-ids and user-name to logs in
production-servers since the context is unique per thread it is a
great way to track a single request.

<extremely-irrelevant>And since I started using http://logback.qos.ch/
the only way I would want to use log4J in a java 5 environmnet is via
slf4j for legacy reasons</extremely-irrelevant>
</off-topic>

On Wed, Mar 26, 2008 at 5:57 PM, Lee B <leeb@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> I miss getName() as well. Here's what I use it for: I often have lots
> of log4j logging messages that spew out of various places (test code
> and code-being-tested) and if a test fails while running from eclipse
> (say), the logging can be quite revealing about where the bug is
> (without having to run the test again with the debugger, etc). With
> Junit3, I always overwrote setUp() and did a simple:
>
> System.out.println("*** running test: " + this.getName());
>
> so that I can easily find the logging messages for that test in the
> sometimes rather lengthy log.
>
> Lee
>
>
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Kent Beck" <kentb@...> wrote:
> >
> > Dear Anthony,
> >
> > There is no easy replacement for getName(). I too often miss that
> convenient
> > object encapsulating the test fixture and the specification of the
> test to
> > be run. What would constitute a good solution depends on what
> problem you
> > are solving with the name. Can you say a little more about this?
> >
> > Regards,
> >
> > Kent Beck
> > Three Rivers Institute
> >
> > _____
> >
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
> > MULLER Anthony
> > Sent: Wednesday, March 26, 2008 5:34 AM
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: [junit] Re: JUnit 3 - compatibility - getName() method
> >
> >
> >
> > I talk about this method:
> > http://junit.
> >
>
> <http://junit.sourceforge.net/javadoc/junit/framework/TestCase.html#getName>
> > sourceforge.net/javadoc/junit/framework/TestCase.html#getName()
> >
> > The getName() method is specific to JUnit 3, it doesn't appear on
> > Object class:
> > http://java.
> <http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/lang/Object.html>
> > sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/lang/Object.html
> >
> > As I said, with JUnit4 you don't need to inherit any class... So how
> > to replace a call to getName() method?
> >
> > Regards,
> > Anthony
> >
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups. <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com> com, "Kamal"
> > <kamal2222ahmed@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Anthony,
> > > Maybe i misunderstood , but as far as i know, the logging mechanism
> > works for Junit 4 as well as Junit 3
> > > and requires minimal plumbing of old code. keep in mind, that
> > getName() and getClass are from JDK. and not Junit.
> > >
> > > This pattern is in the book JUnit recipies by J.B Rainsberger
> > > -Kamal.
> > > ----- Original Message -----
> > > From: MULLER Anthony
> > > To: junit@yahoogroups. <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com> com
> > > Sent: Wednesday, March 26, 2008 7:25 AM
> > > Subject: [junit] Re: JUnit 3 - compatibility - getName() method
> > >
> > >
> > > I think my question was not clear enough.
> > >
> > > In fact, I have many testcases written with JUnit 3.
> > >
> > > Now, I'm trying to move on JUnit4.
> > >
> > > But I have the following problem: I used the method getName() of the
> > > class TestCase. In JUnit 4, you don't have to inherit from this class,
> > > so I 'm looking for "something" to do get the method being executed
> > > (as getName() method did)
> > >
> > > Regards,
> > > Anthony
> > >
> > > --- In junit@yahoogroups. <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com> com,
> "Kamal"
> > <kamal2222ahmed@> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > Anthony,
> > > >
> > > > In your Base Test setUp() , do something like
> > > >
> > > > logger.info("Running Test: " + this.getClass() + "." +
> > > this.getName() + "\n");
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > use log4j or common loggging to setup the logger
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Hope this helps
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > -Kamal.
> > > >
> > > > ----- Original Message -----
> > > > From: MULLER Anthony
> > > > To: junit@yahoogroups. <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com> com

> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Hello!
> > > >
> > > > What is the equivalent method to TestCase.getName() previously in
> > > Junit3 ?
> > > >
> > > > This method returned the method name during the test execution.
> > > >
> > > > Thanks!
> > > >
> > > > Regards,
> > > > Anthony
